answers.answer: Tammy the main thing w. the docs is that they are trying i believe to decide what is the most acute issue that is going on w. your dad.  They have to weigh out the options of which issue is the most life threatening for him and to act on it.  It sounds to me like your dad is probably at a teaching hospital and that is why you have so many docs in and out of his room.  This can obviously be very disconcerting to people.  You do have the right to ask for a single doc to handle his case because you can't handle all fo this confusion.  In this case you are actually looking at two docs....one for the heart and one for the kidney issues.  If it were my dad i would put a stop to this circus because it sounds like it is just making it worse on you and your family.  To me the heart would be the big issue now because he just suffered a heart attack and that is life threatening at the moment.  The one thing you do not want to have happen is for him to suffer another one so soon after because of the end results.  I would put my foot down and tell the chief of staff at the hospital that you would like to meet with him/her and tell them what you are going thru.  You can bet they will put an end to this...a hospitals job is not meant to make things harder physically or emotionally on pts. and their families.  Call the chief of staff and go to the top dog instead of climbing the ladder w. the case manager which still keeps you at the bottom rung and may just add more aggravation to you and your family.  Godspeed to you all and i hope it works out for you Tammy

question: My father has been diagnosed with 90% blockage in three valves, has diabetes, pneumonia and Chronic Kidney Disease - (creatinine levels between 2.1 and 2.8).  He experienced a heart attack 9 days ago and has been hospitalized since.   There are 5 groups of doctors and the plan of action has changed daily and each is giving a varied opinion on whether or not he is ready for a triple by-pass.   Mostly they say he HAS  to have the surgery, but the surgeon is not confident about the outcome with current conditions and a cardiologist told us today that he can opt out.  We are so confused.   Where can we look for answers and is it appropriate to ask for a case manager to put this all together.   Five different doctors come in daily with different opinions.  It is a roller coaster.   My father is 72 - this is the first heart issue but has had diabetes for  17 years and elevated kidney proteins for 5 years.THANKS!
title: Triple by-pass in a diabetic patient with Chronic Kidney Disease
